Comments_List: I learned a ton about the history of bioethics and the relevant issues in the field of bioethics today.

Although I was somewhat familiar with the bioethical issues we discussed (abortion, end-of-life care, stem cell research, etc.), I have no background in law, so it was very cool to learn about the legal guidelines surrounding these issues and the way that constitutional law has been re-interpreted and adapted to apply to new problems.
I learned about the legal basis of many of the most important issues in bioethics (as the name implies).

I learned how to understand case law and how it applies to different jurisdictions.
I learned a lot about bioethics and the legal principals that underpin these things. It made me feel like a more informed citizen and excited to have an opinion about these issues in the real world.

I learned about laws governing informed consent, abortion, end of life care, organ transplantation, etc. I learned a lot about the 14th amendment and how it plays into those topics. Developed a much deeper knowledge of how to evaluate laws morally but also from a constitutional and legal standard. Learned about the basis of many of our fundamental rights and personal rights involving healthcare treatment.

Prof. Latham's lectures are incredibly engagingI really enjoyed the course. I found my section, however, to be weak. There were low expectations of participation and quality of engagement. I did not think that my learning was enhanced at all by my section.

Professor Latham is an excellent, engaging lecturer. The course material is also fascinating and well organized. I guess a weakness would be the extremely large class size, but the subject matter lends itself well to a lecture course, so it wasn't a big issue. Towards the end of the course, the material we covered in section was a day or two ahead of the lecture material, which was slightly inconvenient. Overall, though, the strengths of the course definitely exceeded its weaknesses.

Strengths: Prof. Latham is a great lecturer. When I cared about the topic going into class (I'm thinking specifically of abortion), the environment was electric--Prof. Latham often told each unit as a story, and he was always well-prepared and had his talking points down.
Weaknesses: In my opinion, the exams are not super fair. (This is coming from someone who admittedly didn't put a lot of effort into this class.) The questions were always somewhat open-ended and oftentimes left room for one's own ethics. I understand that there are certain themes and facts and cases from the course that the questions were meant to touch on, but I felt like one could give a complete, well-justified answer that left out one of the buzzwords, and in that case, the TFs' rubric would mark the response down. Also on that note, the TFs are wildly different both in terms of the way section is run and in terms of grading. I'm not sure how to standardize a class this size, but this much variation could likely be mitigated.

I thought the material was very interesting and I definitely felt like I walked out of the class learning a lot. I thought the grading was a bit subjective and therefore I didn't get too much clear feedback overall.

Strengths:
- the readings were very helpful 
- the lecture was very engaging 

Weaknesses:
- the sections were not helpful
- the midterms did not allow for the students to show their full understanding

The course was very interesting but the discussion of material is heavily dependent on your TA; the course is also very large so the difference in knowledge of ethics and law coming into the course between first-years and seniors can make participating in section intimidating.

Professor Latham's lectures are definitely the highlight of the course. He keeps you engaged by including personal stories from the cases and from his own experiences. Moreover, the TA's are very helpful and approachable. I enjoyed going to section and it was helpful in reviewing parts of the course. I wish the class was smaller and that we got to interact with Professor Latham more one on one but I am glad that the course is able to accommodate for all of the students interested in it.
Professor Latham as a lecturer is great. You do not feel bored or the need to distract yourself during the lecture. The way the material is presented also follows a clear chronologic element.

Strengths
-Well organized
-Interesting
-Phenomenal lecturer
-Relevant material
-Fair testing

Weaknesses
-The discussion sections talk about different things and the TAs are too different. My TA (Samantha Godwin) was frequently late, was VERY late with grading, didn't respond to emails, posing confusing questions in section not really relevant to what we would be tested on, etc. I think the sections should be given more clear topics as to what MUST be discussed so it serves as a review time as well.
Information is very interesting and it is well-organized and a cool overview of a very broad field.
Such an interesting and engaging course. I loved it.

Incredibly interesting course, loved all the content! Plus Prof. Latham is an amazing engaging lecturer not to mention a superstar in bioethics! 

Personally, I would prefer a class that focuses much more heavily on theories of justice and philosophical questions behind these issues rather than the primary emphasis of this class on legal outcomes, but I knew what I was signing up for taking this class, and still found it very interesting!

Also, as a minor point, the grading for this class is generous, but incredibly arbitrary. The entire grade is in-class essays, but the range of grades (mostly B to A-) is based more on your ability to write in an organized way under pressure than your knowledge of the course material. It felt like it made no difference whether someone put effort into learning the course material, as that is not what the exams are testing in practice. Still, you will probably end up with a good grade, just hard to get in A if you're not a very fast, strong writer.
More consistency in sections and TAs.

Strengths: AMAZING lectures, great professor, really interesting material, not a huge workload
Weaknesses: not really any.
no weaknesses!
I greatly enjoyed this course. I think the topics are interesting, the methods of testing are fair, and the sections are helpful.
Interesting, not too much work. Maybe too easy to do well without engaging much with the material.
Very interesting course material and very well taught. Section was useful. Not many weaknesses.
The professor is a great lecturer.

Strengths are that the lectures are easy to understand and interesting so you don't dread going to class. Weakness is the exam format. Grading is horribly inconsistent. I think they try to normalize grades across TAs, but some sections are full of try-hard pre-meds and some are full of athletes. So if they normalize then someone who's at the top of one section could be at the bottom of another. Therefore, don't take this class if you're depending on getting an A. The grades seem to be somewhat randomly distributed around B+, with only a moderate correlation to how much knowledge you had about the material. It depends way too much on your TA and how much they like your writing style.

The best way to test this material would be multiple choice. Then you can see what we know and have an objective (and much faster) way to grade the course. It is very possible to write multiple choice questions that are nontrivial and that test a good spectrum of the students' knowledge. I think this class would be perfect for multiple choice.
Professor Latham was super knowledgable and all around a great professor. He knows a TON about this topic and is clearly energetic to share his knowledge.

Feedback on exams could be better, often only provided with a letter grade and no comments or explanation.

It's deceiving as a "gut", because the exams are the entire grade and your TA can make or break your grade in how harshly they grade your essay responses. The actual course also did not seem to be organized too well. It quite literally was like a series of speeches done by the professor each class. It could be better organized.

If you at all interested in bioethics, this class is extremely engaging. The lectures were short enough where I would be able to stay engaged the entire lecture and the topics we discussed were all very interesting. I do wish the course was a little better organized by topic. Oftentimes, after we had moved past a topic, the professor would jump back to fill in gaps that he had missed previously and while it was not that big of an issue, it did make some lectures very disjointed as we would jump from topic to topic with no connections between topics. In addition, I wish we were given sample exams from previous years or something to better prepare us for the exams. As is, I felt like I was not sure how they were going to grade our responses in the first midterm and my grade suffered as a result.
wish there were lecture slides, its a big class so theres very little engagement with the students, but Latham is a great lecturer

Latham is a great professor, and the workload is perfect. The only downside is the grade setup; 25% Midterm 1, 25% Midterm 2, 50% Final. That's just super intimidating. I would suggest making the reading responses (which are mandatory, but not factored into the final grade???) and section attendance worth 10%, and the final 40%. That way you reward the kids who are most engaged with the course, and the final is a little less scary come May.

The course is marketed as bioethics and law, but most of it is law and little time is spent actually discussing bioethics. The grading is too subjective (dependent on the TA, with little transparency regarding expectations or criteria --- in fact, I think each TA has one's own set of criteria), and discussion section quality is also really variant. My TA, for example, led sections that were not interactive and often had long periods of silence. That being said, Latham's eloquence makes up for it. Take the course Credit/D to make the most out of it.

The only weakness was grading -- I felt that there was a complete lack of transparency in grading, and I and all my friends would frequently receive grades with little to know explanation -- or the explanation given was arbitrary and random. I felt that the TFs (and Latham by extension) were looking for any excuse to lower a grade, despite having demonstrated clear mastery over the material. So, while the course is absolutely incredible and the lectures were fascinating and engaging every time, the grading was quite tough and unclear. I never quite figured out exactly was was expected of us, or what an A answer on a midterm would even look like.

Strengths - you don't really have to do the readings for the class, so it is not too much work. Latham is a great lecturer so the lectures go by pretty quickly. Some of the topics (for me, assisted reproduction) can be interesting and even freaky. 

Weaknesses - I really didn't like the grading in the class. There's a rubric for each midterm, which are short essays for different questions. However, the rubric is set up in a way that has a pretty rigid expectation of what the right answer should be, which I felt was unfair since the questions asked in the midterms felt much more open-ended than the rubric allowed. In some respects, I felt like this humanities-esque class was being graded like a STEM class, where questions with multiple right answers were treated like there was only one correct answer. What this grading structure incentivizes is basically throwing everything you know about a topic on the wall and hoping that something sticks (so to speak), instead of actually answering the question. I also think the curve applied to the grading overly penalized wrong answers. For example, in the second midterm, I didn't mention one part of the case law, which to me meant that I missed an eighth of a question, but my grade dropped all the way to a B+ for that one "wrong answer" (even though not much explanation was given for why not mentioning this one part of the case law was such a large mistake that it justified a B+.)

Also, I took this class because I had heard a lot of hype around some of the futuristic topics covered in the class. There are about two weeks where we learn about some truly wild things regarding assisted reproduction, but to be quite honest, most of the topics felt much more mundane. i.e. One class was on the ethical issues surrounding vaccines, a debate that I feel most people know a lot about.

Strength: Lectures were very engaging and discussion section helped hone in on the more confusing parts and clear them up.

The lectures were very engaging, and the topics covered provided both breadth and depth across several different areas of bioethics. Professor Latham was great about emphasizing how different topics fit together or built on one another, which both helped contextualize each new topic within the broader questions of bioethics and also helped prepare us for the final exam along the way. I appreciated that the expectations of us were made very clear - there was little ambiguity about what material we really needed to know. The course is also extremely accessible to students of different areas of academic interest. One area of improvement might be that currently, comparative policy between other nations of the world is given only glancing reference at certain points of the course. Incorporating more awareness of how these issues look different around the world could be really interesting. Also, it wasn't until the end of the course when we had a lecture on global health that it was ever really mentioned that "bioethics" as a whole is an issue arising from great privilege. I think global health warranted more than one lecture. Alternatively, or additionally, we could have had more of a zoomed-out awareness from time to time throughout the course of how the very existence of these debates fits into the global positionality of the US.
Great course, grading was a little harsh though. Easy B, hard A.

The greatest weakness of this course is the way it assesses student knowledge.  Based on the two midterms it seems that the course aggressively curves towards a B+, making it hard to do badly or very well.  Both midterms and finals required writing full essays, each in 25 minutes, and in order to get an A they had to essentially be perfect essays--organization and clarity of argument, as well as hitting on the course information on the rubric (that may have not been explicitly asked for) were both part of the grade.  No matter how well I knew the material and how good of a writer I am in normal circumstances, I simply could not write the quality of essay expected of me to get an A by hand in 25 minutes.  A take home test or short paper would have been a much better way to assess student knowledge.

Stephen Latham is an incredible lecturer - by far the best lecturer I have ever taken a course with at Yale. He is engaging and succinct and the material is so fascinating that I looked forward to class every week and never second guessed my decision to take the course. Although the course material itself is incredible, the structure of the discussion sections varied by TA. Some Was taught completely different things than other TAs and some of the TAs were weak, which made it hard for students to get clear answers to the questions they had. Also, if you didn't understand the material in the textbook, there are limited resources available since the course is almost 100% reliant on the book and lectures. Finally, the way that the exams are structured does not necessarily test how engaged a student has been with the course material but rather rewards those who are good writers and good at spewing BS on a paper in a limited amount of time.

Strengths: Lecture content is extremely interesting. I really liked that we went over the policy and background info behind each major topic before we delved into the major court cases; this provided a very good foundation for each topic, and our discussions of policy were so interesting! Also, assigned supplemental readings that connected our discussions to modern day events were very interesting and enjoyable to read! 

Weaknesses: Discussion sections were interesting, but I did not feel as though they contributed substantially to the course/enhanced my knowledge of lecture content that much. We had some very interesting theoretical discussions that I enjoyed, however, overall, I think section could have been organized better. For example, I think we should have had assigned readings specifically for section so that everyone actually did the readings for class, and I also think that our grade should have been partially based on section participation, because that would have encouraged everyone to take part in discussion. Also, in general, I think the assigned textbook readings for lecture were way too long; they often covered hundreds of pages for one week, so I often had to simply skim through and was never able to finish all of the assigned reading for the week, because there was simply too much to get through. If smaller sections were assigned at a time, I think that would have been helpful, because the textbook did have some very helpful info on the court cases.

I took this course Credit-D and would recommend it to anyone remotely interested in bioethics. I took the class basically because the topics covered sounded like the kinds of things I would enjoy reading about in the newspaper. The legal aspect was totally new to me, and I enjoyed it more than I expected. I found myself reading the casebook kind of like a story: the facts of the case, the arguments for and against, and the court's conclusion. 

And of course, Professor Latham's lectures were an absolute delight. It was a huge privilege to be able to sit in on those lectures twice a week and not have to worry about doing the nitty-gritty of the work for the course. I never, ever got bored during lecture: it was like listening to a bunch of really cool stories from the mouth of someone who has lived them and is incredibly familiar with them. Professor Latham just gets up there and talks, and somehow he manages to weave together the topics into a lecture that is at once entertaining and organized. I really do not know how he does it. If you have the chance to take this course, even to audit it, definitely do that!
